#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Schiphol Airport
#Text=Schiphol Airport ( AMS ) is one of the busiest airports in the world .
#Text=It is southwest of Amsterdam in the Netherlands .
#Text=It serves the city of Amsterdam and the rest of the Netherlands .
#Text=It is one of the major hubs in Europe with flights between many destinations in Asia , Europe and North America .
#Text=It is home to KLM , the Dutch flag carrier airline .
#Text=As of 2016 , Schiphol airport is the third busiest in Europe behind London Heathrow and Paris Charles de Gaulle and ahead of Frankfurt Airport as measured by passenger numbers .
#Text=Orientation
#Text=Schiphol has a one-terminal concept .
#Text=Which means , that all the departure halls are in one building .
#Text=However , this can mean long walks from one connection flight to the other .
#Text=The airport is divided in many different zones .

#Text=The ground floor before security has the entrance of the airport , the railway station ( with the platforms underground ) , the four Arrivals halls , and Schiphol Plaza , the central shopping zone .
#Text=On the 1st floor you can find the check-in desks and Departure Halls 1 , 2 and 3 .
#Text=From this floor you can go to security and passport control if catching a non-Schengen flight and enter the transit area .
#Text=The terminal is divided into three lounges designated 1 , 2 and 3 .
#Text=Piers ( also known as concourses ) connect to these lounges .
#Text=It is possible to walk from one concourse to another , even to those connected to different lounges .
#Text=However , keep in mind that if you 're going from lounge 1 to lounge 2 and 3 you must clear immigration as you are leaving the Schengen area .
#Text=The exception to this is Lounge 4 : it is only connected to Concourse M for low-cost carriers .
#Text=Once past security , passengers in Concourse M cannot access any other lounges or concourses .
#Text=Lounge 4 has very few facilities .
#Text=If catching a connecting flight from one of the M gates , you must exit the secure zone though baggage claim and enter lounge 4 like any departing passenger .
#Text=Few airlines and destinations have a dedicated concourse .
#Text=KLM and Transavia use all gates except for Concourses H and M.
#Text=Lounge 1 consists of concourses B and C , dedicated to Schengen areas .
#Text=Gates D59 through D87 , the Schengen flights departing from gates D are reached by escalator from Lounge 1 .
#Text=Lounge 2 consists of concourses E and gates D3 through D57 ,
#Text=Lounge 3 consists of concourses F , G and H. They serve non-Schengen areas .
#Text=Concourse H is used by low-cost carriers .
#Text=Lounge 4 consists of concourse M , a dedicated Schengen area for low-cost carriers .
#Text=History
#Text=Schiphol opened on 16 September 1916 as a military airbase , with a few barracks and a field serving as platform and runways .
#Text=When civil aircraft started to use the field ( 17 December 1920 ) , it was often called Schiphol-les-bains .
#Text=The Fokker aircraft manufacturer started a factory near Schiphol Airport in 1919 .
#Text=Schiphol 's name is derived from a former fortification named Fort Schiphol which was part of the Defense Line of Amsterdam .
#Text=Before 1852 , the Haarlemmermeer polder in which the airport lies was a large lake , in the shallow waters of which sudden violent storms could claim many ships .
#Text=This was the main reason for reclaiming it .
#Text=In English , Schiphol translates to ' ship grave ' , a reference to the many ships lost in the area .

#Text=KLM was founded on 7 October 1919 by Albert Plesman , making it the oldest carrier in the world still operating under its original name , though the company stopped operating during World War II — apart from the operations in the Dutch Antilles in the Caribbean .
#Text=The first KLM flight was on 17 May 1920 , from Croydon Airport , London to Amsterdam carrying two British journalists and a number of newspapers .
#Text=In 1921 KLM started scheduled services , and by 1926 it was offering flights to Amsterdam , Rotterdam , Brussels , Paris , London , Bremen , Copenhagen and Malmö .
#Text=Intercontinental flights to the Netherlands East Indies started in 1929 .
#Text=This was for several years the world 's longest scheduled air route .
#Text=On 1 November 1958 the airline opened the trans-polar route from Amsterdam via Anchorage to Tokyo .

#Text=Each crew flying the transpolar route over the Arctic was equipped with a winter survival kit , including an AR-10 carbine for use against polar bears in the event the plane was forced down onto the polar ice .
#Text=KLM merged with Air France in May 2004 to form Air France-KLM , but both airlines continue to fly under their distinct brand names .
#Text=Flights
#Text=KLM offers worldwide connections .
#Text=Asia , Europe and North America are particularly well served .
#Text=Delta Air Lines connects Schiphol with nine US destinations .
#Text=British Airways offer up to 15 flights per day to three airports in London .
#Text=Transavia , Easyjet and other low-cost carriers provide a fairly economical way to city-hop to Amsterdam from other cities in Europe .
#Text=Ground transportation

#Text=For most travellers , the most convenient way to reach Amsterdam or other major destinations in the Netherlands from the airport is by train , with most destinations reachable either directly or with one transfer .
#Text=By train
#Text=Most major destinations in the Netherlands can be reached from Schiphol either directly or with a single transfer .
#Text=Use the ticket machines or ticket desks .
#Text=All machines accept credit or debit cards but do require chip-and-PIN cards .

#Text=Alternatively , you can buy an Amsterdam Travel Ticket , which includes a train return ticket to and from Schiphol to any of Amsterdam 's stations , plus unlimited travel on all GVB trams , metro and ( night)buses for 1 , 2 or 3 days .
#Text=The train station at Schiphol is located underground , under the main airport hall ; trains to Amsterdam Centraal usually run from platform 1 or 2 .
#Text=Note : this is not specific , one is never sure which platform it arrives .
#Text=Information signs are updated when the train enters the tunnel .
#Text=It is the same platform , though it matters on which side the train stops .
#Text=This is why you 'll see a lot of locals and tourists waiting just at the end of the escalators or stairs .
#Text=They eventually go to the right track when it is updated .
#Text=For most destinations there are 1 or 2 trains per hour , for more regional destinations trains are more frequent .
#Text=There are 4 to 5 trains per hour between Schiphol and Amsterdam in peak times .
#Text=Regional trains run all night , although between 01:00 and 05:00 only once an hour .
#Text=The price and duration of the journey are the same as during the day .
#Text=However , trains for further destinations will generally not run at night .
#Text=Check before you travel .
#Text=International trains to Belgium or France stop at Schiphol .
#Text=Schiphol to Amsterdam Centraal .
#Text=There are plenty of direct trains from the Schiphol to the Amsterdam Centraal .
#Text=A journey takes 16-18 minutes .
#Text=€ 4.20 if using an OV-chipkaart ; € 5.20 single ticket .
#Text=Schiphol to Amsterdam Lelylaan .
#Text=If your accommodation is located near Vondelpark or Museumplein it 's fastest to catch a train to Amsterdam Lelylaan station and connect to a tram from there .
#Text=Trains leave every 5 to 10 minutes .
#Text=€ 3.00 if using an OV-chipkaart ; € 4.00 single ticket .
#Text=Schiphol to Rotterdam Centraal .
#Text=If traveling to Rotterdam the fastest way to travel is by taking the IC direct that takes you directly to Rotterdam by high-speed rail in 24 minutes .
#Text=€ 14.80 if using an OV-chipkaart ; € 15.80 single ticket .
#Text=Schiphol to Paris Gare du Nord .
#Text=Direct high speed Thalys trains run from Schiphol to Antwerp , Brussels-Midi and Paris .
#Text=Tickets cannot be booked by using the machines at the station and need to be booked in advance or at the ticket office .
#Text=There is no set price so it 's cheapest the earlier you book .
